questions.text: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for severe tearing lower back pain for 12 hours. The pain radiates to the flank, and he describes it as 8 out of 10 in intensity. He has nausea and has vomited several times. He has no fever, diarrhea, or urinary symptoms. When he stands up suddenly, he becomes lightheaded and has to steady himself for approximately 1 to 2 minutes before he is able to walk. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Two years ago, he had a myocardial infarction and underwent coronary artery bypass grafting of his right coronary artery. He has smoked one and a half packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years and drinks 1 to 2 beers daily. His current medications include chlorthalidone, atorvastatin, lisinopril, and aspirin. He appears acutely ill. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 130/min and regular, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 80/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. Examination shows a pulsatile mass in the abdomen. Intravenous fluids and high-flow oxygen are started. Thirty minutes later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The risk of developing an AAA is 8–9 times higher among individuals 70–74 years of age compared to those between the ages of 25 and 54. Age is not, however, the strongest risk factor in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

The risk of developing an AAA is 3–4 times higher among hyperlipidemic patients compared to those with a normal lipid profile. Hyperlipidemia is not, however, the strongest risk factor for AAA.

C) INCORRECT:

The risk of developing an AAA is 2–3 times higher in men than in women. In contrast, the risk of AAA rupture appears to be slightly higher in women. This patient's sex is not his strongest risk factor.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypertension is the strongest risk factor for aortic dissection, which can manifest with severe tearing pain and hypotension. However, a pulsatile abdominal mass is not expected in aortic dissection. This patient most likely had an AAA complicated by rupture. Hypertension is not the strongest predisposing factor for AAA or AAA rupture.

E) CORRECT:

A history of smoking is the strongest independent risk factor for the development and growth of an AAA. The risk of a clinically detectable aneurysm, as seen in this patient with 60 pack-years of smoking, may be up to 25 times greater than in a man the same age who has never smoked. Because smoking increases the risk of AAA so dramatically, the US Preventive Services Task Force recommends a single screening ultrasound for all males with a history of smoking between the ages of 65 and 75. Refraining from or quitting smoking is also the single most important measure for preventing AAA.

Risk factors for AAA rupture include a large aneurysm diameter (> 5.5 cm), rapid expansion rate (> 1 cm/year), and smoking.
Image Description:

Left: ultrasound abdomen (transverse plane); right: CT abdomen (without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of AAA and increasing mid abdominal pain over 24 hours

Luminal thrombus is heterogeneous on point-of-care ultrasound performed in the emergency room. An elongated hypoechoic area projecting from the right side of the aorta (red overlay) is suspicious for para-aortic hemorrhage from rupture of the aneurysm.

Intermittent calcification helps define the aortic wall on CT. The extent of a large right retroperitoneal hematoma (green overlay) is well demonstrated. The attenuation of the collection is compatible with subacute hemorrhage.

A: aneurysmal abdominal aorta
questions.hint: Sudden-onset, severe tearing lower back pain and signs of hypovolemic shock (hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea) in a patient with a pulsatile abdominal mass indicate ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).

questions.text: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 30-minute history of severe abdominal pain radiating to his left flank. He is weak and has been unable to stand since the onset of the pain. He vomited twice on the way to the hospital. He has not passed stools for 3 days. He has hypertension, coronary heart disease, and peptic ulcer disease. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 46 years. Current medications include enalapril, metoprolol, aspirin, simvastatin, and pantoprazole. He appears ill. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 131/min, respirations are 31/min, and blood pressure is 82/56 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows a painful pulsatile abdominal mass. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Supine and erect x-rays of the abdomen
CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast
Transfusion of packed red blood cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous antibiotic therapy, e.g., a regimen of ampicillin and sulbactam, would be appropriate for treating a patient with uncomplicated diverticulitis after imaging studies (e.g., abdominal CT) have established the diagnosis. In some cases, diverticulitis may cause septic shock, which could resemble this patient's condition. However, diverticulitis is usually a local colonic infection that presents with subacute nonradiating LLQ pain, signs of systemic infection (e.g., fever), and in the case of peritonitis, abdominal guarding, none of which are present in this patient. Regardless, if this patient did have septic shock secondary to diverticulitis, emergency surgery would likely be necessary to control the infectious focus rather than a course of IV antibiotics.

B) INCORRECT:

Supine and erect x-rays of the abdomen would be the most appropriate next step if a perforated viscus or bowel obstruction were suspected. This patient's PUD and aspirin use put him at risk of a ruptured ulcer. However, his history is not consistent with an active ulcer given his use of pantoprazole as well as the absence of any recent epigastric pain or abdominal distention and rigidity. Although the patient has signs of bowel obstruction (vomiting, no bowel movement in three days), it is less likely than AAA because obstructions usually have worsening pain over hours to days and would not cause sudden hemodynamic instability.

Rupture of an ulcer on the posterior duodenum or lesser stomach curvature can also result in bleeding from the gastroduodenal or the left gastric artery, respectively. Bleeding from either of these arteries could present with signs of hemorrhagic shock from intravascular blood loss, as seen in this patient. However, it would not present with a pulsatile mass.

C) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast would be an appropriate confirmatory test in a hemodynamically stable patient with a suspected AAA rupture, especially when other conditions might explain the findings, e.g., bowel ischemia or perforation. However, this patient already has a classic triad of a ruptured AAA and signs of severe hemorrhagic shock. Imaging must not delay definitive treatment.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; arterial phase; axial plane)

An infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm is measured as 8 cm in transverse diameter. Contrast extravasation (dashed outline) is seen on the left side at the site of rupture (arrowhead). A large left retroperitoneal hematoma (yellow overlay) extends inferiorly into the inguinal canal. Additional intraperitoneal fluid is seen in the pelvis and right upper quadrant (red overlay).

D) CORRECT:

Open emergency surgery is the most appropriate next step for this patient who most likely has an AAA rupture. The findings of hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea indicate that this patient is in severe hemorrhagic shock. In a hemodynamically unstable patient with a high clinical suspicion for ruptured AAA, treatment should not be delayed for any confirmatory imaging. An alternative to open surgery is endovascular aneurysm repair, which is recommended over open surgery in current guidelines if it is anatomically feasible. Without immediate repair, AAA rupture is usually fatal within hours.

E) INCORRECT:

Transfusion of packed RBCs will very likely be required for this patient in order to offset intravascular blood volume loss. In fact, in any patient with a ruptured AAA, at least 10 units of packed RBCs should be ready for likely transfusion intraoperatively, as these patients lose significant amounts of blood. While a blood transfusion may temporarily help to counter volume loss, this patient needs immediate definitive treatment to contain further bleeding.
questions.hint: This patient has several risk factors for cardiovascular disease, including his age, sex, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and a history of smoking. The triad of back or abdominal pain, hypotension, and a pulsatile abdominal mass indicates a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. Over the past year, he has had problems initiating urination and the sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. He does not drink alcohol. His medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and daily aspirin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a pulsatile abdominal mass at the level of the umbilicus and a bruit on auscultation. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, nontender prostate with rubbery texture. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography of the abdomen and pelvis is appropriate for hemodynamically stable patients with confirmed or suspected symptomatic AAA. This test provides a detailed assessment of the location, size, and extent of the aneurysm, as well as the involvement of branch vessels, presence of a thrombus, and/or rupture. Signs of symptomatic AAA include abdominal, back, or flank pain, flank ecchymoses, and signs of aortic fistula (e.g., heart failure, upper gastrointestinal bleeding), which this patient does not have. A different step in management is more appropriate for asymptomatic AAA.
Image Description:

Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen (transverse section at L3; arterial phase)

Infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (5 x 5.5 cm) with peripheral, hypodense thrombotic material (red overlay) and central, hyperdense contrast-enhanced blood (green overlay). A light calcification of the aortic wall is visible (red outline).

B) INCORRECT:

Intraoperative catheter arteriography of the aorta can be used to assess the intraluminal space and the presence of a leak after repair of an AAA. However, it has limited use during diagnostic workup, as it only assesses the aortic lumen and cannot distinguish between the vessel wall and a blood clot in an aneurysm (and thus cannot estimate aneurysm size).

C) INCORRECT:

A prostate biopsy would be appropriate for a patient with a high suspicion for prostate cancer (e.g., presence of constitutional symptoms, terminal hematuria). However, this patient's urinary symptoms (hesitancy and incomplete voiding), in combination with a digital rectal examination showing a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, nontender prostate with rubbery texture, are consistent with benign prostatic hyperplasia. This does not merit urgent management at this time, particularly in this patient with findings suspicious for an AAA.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels are a nonspecific finding in several conditions that affect the prostate, including prostate cancer and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). This patient's urinary symptoms (hesitancy and incomplete voiding), in combination with a digital rectal examination showing a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, nontender prostate with rubbery texture, are consistent with BPH. This does not merit urgent management at this time, particularly in this patient with findings suspicious for an AAA.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with a suspected asymptomatic AAA should undergo abdominal ultrasonography to confirm the diagnosis (dilatation of the aorta ≥ 3 cm) and evaluate the extent of disease, including location and size of the aneurysm, presence of a blood clot, and presence of comorbid iliac artery aneurysms. The sensitivity and specificity of abdominal ultrasonography for AAA are nearly 100%. After the diagnosis is established, management strategies depend on the risk factors for rupture (e.g., aneurysm diameter and rate of expansion).

F) INCORRECT:

Renal arteriography is the gold standard for diagnosing renal artery stenosis (RAS), which can also present with an abdominal bruit. However, additional clinical features include treatment-resistant hypertension and hypokalemia (from elevated aldosterone levels) and elevated serum creatinine concentration, which this patient does not have. Other diagnostic methods for workup of RAS include renal ultrasonography, CT angiography, and MR angiography.
questions.hint: This patient has a history of smoking, hypercholesterolemia, and arterial hypertension and presents with a pulsatile abdominal mass and a bruit on auscultation. These features are suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He does not have abdominal, back, or flank pain, flank ecchymoses, or signs of hemodynamic instability that would suggest rupture.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician for follow-up care. One year ago, she was diagnosed with a 4-cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm found incidentally on abdominal ultrasound. She says she feels well. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and COPD. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, glyburide, and an albuterol inhaler. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Examination shows a faint abdominal bruit on auscultation. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows a 5.1-cm saccular dilation of the infrarenal aorta. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and follow-up CT in 12 months
Adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and follow-up CT in 6 months
Adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and follow-up ultrasound in 6 months
Adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and follow-up ultrasound in 12 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conservative management of AAA includes adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and aneurysm surveillance. This approach is indicated for an asymptomatic AAA that is not rapidly expanding and is < 5.5 cm in men or < 5 cm in women. In addition, duplex ultrasonography is the preferred imaging modality for AAA surveillance because it is as accurate as CT angiography for assessing aneurysm diameter, less expensive, and does not require administration of IV contrast or radiation exposure.

B) INCORRECT:

Conservative management of AAA includes adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and aneurysm surveillance. This approach is indicated for an asymptomatic AAA that is not rapidly expanding and is < 5.5 cm in men or < 5 cm in women. In addition, duplex ultrasonography is the preferred imaging modality for AAA surveillance because it is as accurate as CT angiography for assessing aneurysm diameter, less expensive, and does not require administration of IV contrast or radiation exposure.

C) CORRECT:

Elective surgical repair is indicated for large asymptomatic AAAs (≥ 5.5 cm in men; ≥ 5.0 cm in women), rapidly expanding AAAs (≥ 0.5 cm/6 months), saccular aneurysms, and/or symptomatic AAAs (as these are most likely to rupture) regardless of size. This patient has a saccular AAA that has rapidly grown over the past year and therefore requires surgery. Endovascular aneurysm repair is recommended for AAA in patients with suitable anatomy because it is minimally invasive and can be performed under local anesthesia. Furthermore, this approach is preferred in individuals with high operative risk, such as this patient with multiple comorbidities.

D) INCORRECT:

Although elective surgical repair is indicated for this patient's AAA, she has a high operative risk due to multiple comorbidities. Another step in management is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Conservative management of AAA includes adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and aneurysm surveillance with ultrasound. This approach is indicated for an asymptomatic AAA that is not rapidly expanding and is < 5.5 cm in men or < 5 cm in women (see “Follow-up frequency for AAA surveillance” table). Elective repair rather than conservative management is indicated for a rapidly expanding AAA.

F) INCORRECT:

Conservative management of AAA includes adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and aneurysm surveillance with ultrasound. This approach is indicated for an asymptomatic AAA that is not rapidly expanding and is < 5.5 cm in men or < 5 cm in women (see “Follow-up frequency for AAA surveillance” table). Elective repair rather than conservative management is indicated for a rapidly expanding AAA.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a rapidly expanding abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).

questions.text: A 71-year-old man with hypertension is taken to the emergency department after the sudden onset of stabbing abdominal pain that radiates to the back. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. His pulse is 120/min and thready, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 82/54 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a periumbilical, pulsatile mass and abdominal bruit. There is epigastric tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coronary atherosclerosis resulting in narrowing of the vessel lumen is involved in the pathophysiology of angina pectoris and myocardial infarction (MI). Coronary atherosclerosis leads to narrowing of the arterial lumen, which decreases the blood flow to the myocardium. During exercise, myocardial flow is unable to meet increased myocardial demand, which causes myocardial ischemia and symptoms of angina. While smoking increases the risk for MI, this man's history of acute onset, stabbing abdominal pain with an umbilical mass and hypotension suggest a different disease process.

B) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The pathophysiology of AAA is not fully understood, but numerous genetic and environmental factors, such as smoking, are believed to cause inflammation and proteolysis of connective tissue within the aortic wall. This leads to loss of structural integrity and weakening of the aorta. Other risk factors for AAA include advanced age and male sex. When high aortic wall stress is applied, as in hypertension, further weakening, widening, and rupture of the aortic wall can occur. AAAs are most commonly located below the renal arteries (infrarenal).
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; arterial phase; axial plane)

An infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm is measured as 8 cm in transverse diameter. Contrast extravasation (dashed outline) is seen on the left side at the site of rupture (arrowhead). A large left retroperitoneal hematoma (yellow overlay) extends inferiorly into the inguinal canal. Additional intraperitoneal fluid is seen in the pelvis and right upper quadrant (red overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Mesenteric atherosclerosis is involved in the pathophysiology of chronic mesenteric ischemia, in which intestinal blood flow is reduced. In the postprandial period, there is a mismatch between low splanchnic blood flow and high intestinal metabolic demand, which leads to postprandial ischemia and abdominal pain within one hour of eating. Bloating, nausea, and weight loss due to food aversion are common symptoms. This patient has acute-onset, stabbing abdominal pain with an umbilical mass and hypotension, features that suggest a different, more emergent disease process.

D) INCORRECT:

Gastric mucosal ulceration is involved in the pathophysiology of peptic ulcer disease. One of the complications of this disease is gastric or duodenal perforation, which manifests with sudden onset, stabbing abdominal pain, and distention that can progress to peritonitis. This patient's periumbilical mass, abdominal bruit, and hypotension are inconsistent with a perforated duodenal or gastric ulcer.

E) INCORRECT:

Abdominal wall defects can predispose patients to hernia formation. Uncomplicated hernias are typically asymptomatic and occur when intraabdominal contents protrude through congenital defects or areas of weakness in the abdominal wall. Complicated hernias include incarcerated hernias (irreducible), strangulated hernias (disrupted blood supply), or obstructed hernias (kinked intestine), and typically manifest with acute pain at the site of the hernia and possible bowel obstruction. Although this patient has a periumbilical mass, he also has an abdominal bruit and hypotension, suggesting a different etiology for his symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Portal vein stasis predisposes patients to the formation of acute portal vein thrombosis, which manifests with right upper quadrant or generalized abdominal pain. Portal vein thrombosis often arises as a complication of cirrhosis, but this patient lacks symptoms of chronic liver disease (jaundice, pruritus, hepatosplenomegaly, telangiectasias, caput medusae, gynecomastia). Furthermore, this patient's periumbilical mass and abdominal bruit suggest a different cause for his symptoms.
questions.hint: Abdominal pain radiating to the back, a pulsatile abdominal mass, and new-onset hypotension in a man with a history of smoking and hypertension should raise concerns for a certain pathology.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of intermittent dull abdominal pain that radiates to the back. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. His blood pressure is 145/80 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows generalized tenderness and a pulsatile mass in the periumbilical region on deep palpation. Further evaluation of the affected blood vessel is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Accumulation of foam cells in the tunica intima
Obliterative inflammation of the vasa vasorum
Necrotizing inflammation of the entire vessel wall
Formation of giant cells in the tunica media
Fragmentation of elastic tissue in the tunica media

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Accumulation of foam cells in the tunica intima is the pathological process underlying atheroma formation (atherosclerosis), which is the most common cause of aortic wall weakening and formation of an AAA. This patient's history of smoking, hypertension, and advanced age are all risk factors for atherosclerosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a section of an arterial wall depicting an atheroma (H&E, highly magnified)

The inner layer of an atheroma is the single layer of endothelial cells of the tunica intima (the superior-most layer in this image).
The second layer is a fibrous cap, which is composed of lipid-laden macrophages or foam cells (the white arrowheads point to a few examples), a few smooth muscle cells, neutrophils, and lymphocytes.
The core of the atheroma (green overlay) is composed of anuclear necrotic cells and cholesterol clefts (empty unstained spaced indicated with white arrows).

A collection of foam cells and cholesterol clefts with a fibrous cap and a necrotic core are the characteristic histological features of an atheroma.

B) INCORRECT:

Obliterative inflammation of the vasa vasorum is characteristic of syphilitic aortitis, which can result in an aortic aneurysm. However, syphilitic aortitis affects the ascending aorta, whereas this patient presents with a mass in the abdominal portion of the descending aorta.

C) INCORRECT:

Necrotizing inflammation of all the layers of the vessel wall is characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), which can cause microaneurysms in medium-sized arteries (e.g., mesenteric arteries and renal arteries), episodic abdominal pain (due to mesenteric ischemia), and hypertension (due to renal involvement). However, PAN would not cause a pulsatile periumbilical mass because it spares large arteries like the aorta. Other clinical features of vasculitis, such as fever, malaise, weight loss, and cutaneous lesions (e.g., livedo reticularis, distal ulcerations), would be expected instead.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a muscle biopsy sample with a medium-sized arterial vessel (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.

These findings are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.

D) INCORRECT:

Formation of giant cells in the tunica media is characteristic of giant cell arteritis (GCA) and Takayasu arteritis, both of which are large vessel vasculitides and can result in an AAA. However, neither condition is the most common cause of AAA, and this patient does not report any symptoms that would otherwise suggest an increased likelihood of GCA (e.g., headache, scalp tenderness, or jaw claudication) or Takayasu arteritis (e.g., limb claudication or onset of symptoms before the age of 40 years), so a different pathological process is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Fragmentation of elastic tissue in the tunica media is the pathological process underlying cystic medial necrosis (CMN), which occurs in certain connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome. However, for reasons that are not completely understood, CMN typically affects the thoracic aorta rather than the abdominal aorta. A different pathological process is the most common cause of an AAA. Furthermore, this patient does not have features of Marfan syndrome (e.g., tall stature, long extremities, joint hypermobility, ectopia lentis).
questions.hint: The presence of chronic dull abdominal pain and a pulsatile abdominal mass suggests an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician for a health maintenance examination. He feels well. His last visit to the office was 6 years ago. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and carotid artery stenosis for which he takes metformin, lisinopril, simvastatin, and aspirin. His father died from an ischemic stroke at the age of 74 years. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but stopped 25 years ago. He drinks two 12-oz beers weekly. Immunizations are up-to-date and a colonoscopy performed 8 years ago was unremarkable. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. His pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, no adenomatous polyps, no family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). The previously recommended age to start screening was 50 years. Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had his last colonoscopy 8 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), a colonoscopy is not indicated at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's hypertension, history of smoking, and advanced age increase the risk of developing an intracranial aneurysm. However, screening in asymptomatic patients is not indicated in the general population because it is not cost-effective, owing to the prevalence being too low and these aneurysms having a low risk of rupture. Screening may be considered in patients with genetic conditions associated with a higher incidence of intracranial aneurysms (e.g., autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) and in patients with first-degree relatives with a history of intracranial aneurysms, neither of which is seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends annual screening with a low-dose CT scan of the chest in patients 50–80 years of age who have at least a 20 pack-year smoking history and who are current smokers or have stopped within the past 15 years. This patient has a 20 pack-year smoking history, but he stopped smoking 25 years ago. A low-dose CT scan of the chest is, therefore, not recommended at this time.

D) CORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends that men 65–75 years of age who are current or former smokers should receive a one-time screening with ultrasonography for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Ultrasonography can determine the presence and size of an aneurysm, as well as the presence of a blood clot in an aneurysm. It is also the modality of choice for monitoring patients with small, asymptomatic AAAs.

E) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends osteoporosis screening with bone densitometry scan every 10 years for women aged 65 years or older. Although some suggest a one-time screening for men older than 70 years of age, there is insufficient evidence to suggest that screening is beneficial in younger men. Therefore, screening for osteoporosis is not indicated in this patient.
questions.hint: The United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening for this condition in men 65–75 years of age who are current or former smokers.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a history of smoking (he quit 20 years ago). His physical examination is unremarkable. He feels well and lives independently.
Which one of the following screening tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the absence of symptoms, carotid ultrasonography is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Some guidelines suggest routine screening bone densitometry for high-risk men over the age of 70 and for men over the age of 50 who have major risk factors, such as chronic glucocorticoid use or untreated hypogonadism, but other guidelines (such as USPSTF) do not recommend routine bone densitometry for men. A history of cigarette smoking is considered a minor risk factor for osteoporosis and is therefore not an indication for osteoporosis screening.

C) CORRECT:

The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends one-time screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) by ultrasonography in men 65 to 75 years of age who have ever smoked (grade B recommendation). The USPSTF cites good evidence that AAA screening and surgical repair of large AAAs (≥5.5 cm in diameter) in this cohort reduces AAA-specific mortality. For men 65 to 75 years of age who have never smoked, the USPSTF recommends selectively offering AAA screening rather than routinely offering it (grade C recommendation). For women in this age group, the USPSTF states that there is insufficient evidence to assess the risks and benefits of AAA screening for those who have ever smoked (I recommendation), and it advises against routine screening for those who have never smoked (grade D recommendation).

Some guidelines, such as those issued in 2018 from the Society for Vascular Surgery, recommend more aggressive screening, with ultrasound in both men and women aged 65 to 75 years who have ever smoked or who have a family history of AAA — and in older individuals with these risk factors if they are in good health and have not already received a screening test.

Key learning point: The recommended screening test for men 65 to 75 years of age who have ever smoked is ultrasound of the abdominal aorta.

D) INCORRECT:

In a patient with hypertension, urinalysis (for proteinuria) and a resting electrocardiogram (for left ventricular hypertrophy) are recommended, but an exercise electrocardiogram and an echocardiogram are not.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient with hypertension, urinalysis (for proteinuria) and a resting electrocardiogram (for left ventricular hypertrophy) are recommended, but an exercise electrocardiogram and an echocardiogram are not.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old woman presents to establish primary care. She reports no prior medical problems and takes no medications. She has a past history of cigarette smoking. On review of symptoms, she reports recent “heaviness” in both legs when she tries to walk.
On examination, her blood pressure is 128/70 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 80 beats per minute. A pulsatile mass is palpable in the mid-abdomen. She has bilateral femoral bruits. Her lower-extremity pulses are diminished bilaterally.
Abdominal ultrasound reveals a 5.9-cm-diameter aortic aneurysm with intramural thrombus.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in caring for this patient?

choices.text: Refer for elective surgical repair of the aneurysm
Refer the patient to a cardiac rehabilitation program

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Surgical treatment should not be delayed for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) that is 5.9 cm in diameter.

The rate of rupture of an AAA depends on the patient’s sex, the size of the aneurysm at the time of diagnosis, and the rate of expansion. The approximate annual rate of rupture for an AAA that is 5.0 cm to 6.9 cm in diameter is 3% to 15%, with rupture occurring at smaller diameters for women. Based on these data and studies assessing various thresholds for intervention, guidelines recommend surveillance until the aneurysm diameter is ≥5.5 cm in men or ≥5.0 cm in women. This approach is safe and is associated with a very low rate of rupture (approximately 1% per year). Other risk factors for AAA rupture include smoking, poor blood pressure control, and low FEV1 .

Key learning point: Elective surgical repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm is strongly recommended when the diameter is ≥5.5 cm in men or ≥5.0 cm in women.
Image Description:

AAA: abdominal aortic aneurysm
CTA: computed tomography angiography
MRA: magnetic resonance angiography

B) INCORRECT:

The presence of intramural thrombus is not an indication for anticoagulation.

C) INCORRECT:

Referral to cardiac rehabilitation should be considered after the AAA is repaired surgically.

D) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic therapies directed at limiting AAA expansion and preventing rupture are not effective; thus, starting an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor would not be indicated in this patient with a normal blood pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

A stress test to evaluate a patient with an AAA may be indicated, but an exercise-type stress test would not be appropriate for this patient given her history of claudication.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension and a remote 10-pack-year history of cigarette smoking presents for his annual visit. He has been feeling well without any symptoms. His blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 72 beats per minute. His physical examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following screening tests is indicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Screening carotid ultrasound and pancreatic imaging are not recommended for asymptomatic adults.

B) CORRECT:

Risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) include older age, male sex, a history of cigarette smoking, and a first-degree relative with a history of AAA. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends a one-time AAA screening ultrasound in men aged 65 to 75 years who have ever smoked; this recommendation is based on data showing an association between screening and a reduction in AAA-related mortality. For men 65 to 75 years of age who have never smoked, the USPSTF recommends selectively offering AAA screening rather than routinely offering it (grade C recommendation). For women in this age group, the USPSTF states that there is insufficient evidence to assess the risks and benefits of AAA screening for those who have ever smoked (grade I recommendation), and it advises against routine screening for those who have never smoked (grade D recommendation).

Some guidelines, such as those issued in 2018 from the Society for Vascular Surgery, recommend more aggressive screening, with ultrasound in both men and women aged 65 to 75 years who have ever smoked or who have a family history of AAA — and in older individuals with these risk factors if they are in good health and have not already received a screening test.

Key learning point: The indicated screening test for a 70-year-old man who has a 10-pack-year history of cigarette smoking is ultrasound of the abdominal aorta.

C) INCORRECT:

Screening carotid ultrasound and pancreatic imaging are not recommended for asymptomatic adults.

D) INCORRECT:

Resting or exercise treadmill testing with electrocardiography to predict coronary artery disease events is not recommended for asymptomatic adults who are at low risk for such events.

E) INCORRECT:

According to USPSTF guidelines, annual low-dose CT of the chest is appropriate for current smokers (or those who have quit within the past 15 years) who are between the ages of 50 and 80 years and have at least a 20-pack-year history of cigarette smoking.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a history of smoking (he quit 20 years ago). His physical examination is unremarkable. He feels well and lives independently. Which one of the following screening tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the absence of symptoms, carotid ultrasonography is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Some guidelines suggest routine screening bone densitometry for high-risk men over the age of 70 and for men over the age of 50 who have major risk factors, such as chronic glucocorticoid use or untreated hypogonadism, but other guidelines (such as USPSTF) do not recommend routine bone densitometry for men. A history of cigarette smoking is considered a minor risk factor for osteoporosis and is therefore not an indication for osteoporosis screening.

C) CORRECT:

The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends one-time screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) by ultrasonography in men 65 to 75 years of age who have ever smoked (grade B recommendation). The USPSTF cites good evidence that AAA screening and surgical repair of large AAAs (≥5.5 cm in diameter) in this cohort reduces AAA-specific mortality. For men 65 to 75 years of age who have never smoked, the USPSTF recommends selectively offering AAA screening rather than routinely offering it (grade C recommendation). For women in this age group, the USPSTF states that there is insufficient evidence to assess the risks and benefits of AAA screening for those who have ever smoked (I recommendation), and it advises against routine screening for those who have never smoked (grade D recommendation).

Some guidelines, such as those issued in 2018 from the Society for Vascular Surgery, recommend more aggressive screening, with ultrasound in both men and women aged 65 to 75 years who have ever smoked or who have a family history of AAA — and in older individuals with these risk factors if they are in good health and have not already received a screening test.

Key learning point: The recommended screening test for men 65 to 75 years of age who have ever smoked is ultrasound of the abdominal aorta.

D) INCORRECT:

In a patient with hypertension, urinalysis (for proteinuria) and a resting electrocardiogram (for left ventricular hypertrophy) are recommended, but an exercise electrocardiogram and an echocardiogram are not.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient with hypertension, urinalysis (for proteinuria) and a resting electrocardiogram (for left ventricular hypertrophy) are recommended, but an exercise electrocardiogram and an echocardiogram are not.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. Over the past year, he has had problems initiating urination and the sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. His medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and daily aspirin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a pulsatile abdominal mass at the level of the umbilicus and a bruit on auscultation. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, nontender prostate with rubbery texture. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography of the abdomen and pelvis is appropriate for hemodynamically stable patients with confirmed or suspected symptomatic AAA. This test provides a detailed assessment of the location, size, and extent of the aneurysm, as well as the involvement of branch vessels, presence of a thrombus, and/or rupture. Signs of symptomatic AAA include abdominal, back, or flank pain, flank ecchymoses, and signs of aortic fistula (e.g., heart failure, upper gastrointestinal bleeding), which this patient does not have. A different step in management is more appropriate for asymptomatic AAA.
Image Description:

Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen (transverse section at L3; arterial phase)

Infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (5 x 5.5 cm) with peripheral, hypodense thrombotic material (red overlay) and central, hyperdense contrast-enhanced blood (green overlay). A light calcification of the aortic wall is visible (red outline).

B) INCORRECT:

A prostate biopsy would be appropriate for a patient with a high suspicion for prostate cancer (e.g., presence of constitutional symptoms, terminal hematuria). However, this patient's urinary symptoms (hesitancy and incomplete voiding), in combination with a digital rectal examination showing a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, nontender prostate with rubbery texture, are consistent with benign prostatic hyperplasia. This does not merit urgent management at this time, particularly in this patient with findings suspicious for an AAA.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels are a nonspecific finding in several conditions that affect the prostate, including prostate cancer and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). This patient's urinary symptoms (hesitancy and incomplete voiding), in combination with a digital rectal examination showing a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, nontender prostate with rubbery texture, are consistent with BPH. This does not merit urgent management at this time, particularly in this patient with findings suspicious for an AAA.

D) CORRECT:

Patients with a suspected asymptomatic AAA should undergo abdominal ultrasonography to confirm the diagnosis (dilatation of the aorta ≥ 3 cm) and evaluate the extent of disease, including location and size of the aneurysm, presence of a blood clot, and presence of comorbid iliac artery aneurysms. The sensitivity and specificity of abdominal ultrasonography for AAA are nearly 100%. After the diagnosis is established, management strategies depend on the risk factors for rupture (e.g., aneurysm diameter and rate of expansion).

Key learning point: Abdominal ultrasonography is the preferred initial diagnostic test for suspected asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm due to its high sensitivity, specificity, and ability to assess aneurysm size and extent.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal arteriography is the gold standard for diagnosing renal artery stenosis (RAS), which can also present with an abdominal bruit. However, additional clinical features include treatment-resistant hypertension and hypokalemia (from elevated aldosterone levels) and elevated serum creatinine concentration, which this patient does not have. Other diagnostic methods for workup of RAS include renal ultrasonography, CT angiography, and MR angiography.
questions.hint: This patient has a history of smoking, hypercholesterolemia, and arterial hypertension and presents with a pulsatile abdominal mass and a bruit on auscultation. These features are suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He does not have abdominal, back, or flank pain, flank ecchymoses, or signs of hemodynamic instability that would suggest rupture.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of intermittent dull abdominal pain that radiates to the back. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. His blood pressure is 145/80 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows generalized tenderness and a pulsatile mass in the periumbilical region on deep palpation. Further evaluation of the affected blood vessel is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Accumulation of foam cells in the tunica intima
Obliterative inflammation of the vasa vasorum
Necrotizing inflammation of the entire vessel wall
Formation of giant cells in the tunica media
Fragmentation of elastic tissue in the tunica media

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Accumulation of foam cells in the tunica intima is the pathological process underlying atheroma formation (atherosclerosis), which is the most common cause of aortic wall weakening and formation of an AAA. This patient's history of smoking, hypertension, and advanced age are all risk factors for atherosclerosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a section of an arterial wall depicting an atheroma (H&E, highly magnified)

The inner layer of an atheroma is the single layer of endothelial cells of the tunica intima (the superior-most layer in this image).
The second layer is a fibrous cap, which is composed of lipid-laden macrophages or foam cells (the white arrowheads point to a few examples), a few smooth muscle cells, neutrophils, and lymphocytes.
The core of the atheroma (green overlay) is composed of anuclear necrotic cells and cholesterol clefts (empty unstained spaced indicated with white arrows).

A collection of foam cells and cholesterol clefts with a fibrous cap and a necrotic core are the characteristic histological features of an atheroma.

B) INCORRECT:

Obliterative inflammation of the vasa vasorum is characteristic of syphilitic aortitis, which can result in an aortic aneurysm. However, syphilitic aortitis affects the ascending aorta, whereas this patient presents with a mass in the abdominal portion of the descending aorta.

C) INCORRECT:

Necrotizing inflammation of all the layers of the vessel wall is characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), which can cause microaneurysms in medium-sized arteries (e.g., mesenteric arteries and renal arteries), episodic abdominal pain (due to mesenteric ischemia), and hypertension (due to renal involvement). However, PAN would not cause a pulsatile periumbilical mass because it spares large arteries like the aorta. Other clinical features of vasculitis, such as fever, malaise, weight loss, and cutaneous lesions (e.g., livedo reticularis, distal ulcerations), would be expected instead.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a muscle biopsy sample with a medium-sized arterial vessel (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.

These findings are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.

D) INCORRECT:

Formation of giant cells in the tunica media is characteristic of giant cell arteritis (GCA) and Takayasu arteritis, both of which are large vessel vasculitides and can result in an AAA. However, neither condition is the most common cause of AAA, and this patient does not report any symptoms that would otherwise suggest an increased likelihood of GCA (e.g., headache, scalp tenderness, or jaw claudication) or Takayasu arteritis (e.g., limb claudication or onset of symptoms before the age of 40 years), so a different pathological process is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Fragmentation of elastic tissue in the tunica media is the pathological process underlying cystic medial necrosis (CMN), which occurs in certain connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome. However, for reasons that are not completely understood, CMN typically affects the thoracic aorta rather than the abdominal aorta. A different pathological process is the most common cause of an AAA. Furthermore, this patient does not have features of Marfan syndrome (e.g., tall stature, long extremities, joint hypermobility, ectopia lentis).
questions.hint: The presence of chronic dull abdominal pain and a pulsatile abdominal mass suggests an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of severe abdominal pain and nausea. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks alcoholic beverages occasionally. His pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 142/86 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Abdominal examination shows a pulsatile epigastric mass and diffuse tenderness. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Filling defect in the superior mesenteric vein

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An increased serum lipase concentration is seen in patients with acute pancreatitis, which causes acute abdominal pain and nausea and can result in an epigastric mass (pancreatic pseudocyst). However, pancreatic pseudocysts are typically nonpulsatile and develop days to weeks after an initial episode of acute pancreatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

An absent hepatojugular reflux suggests hepatic venous outflow obstruction, which can be seen in patients with Budd-Chiari syndrome. This condition can cause abdominal pain and nausea but is not associated with a pulsatile abdominal mass. In addition, this patient lacks additional features of Budd-Chiari syndrome, such as hepatomegaly and ascites, and lacks risk factors for hepatic vein obstruction such as hypercoagulability.

C) INCORRECT:

A filling defect in the superior mesenteric vein can result from mesenteric venous thrombosis (MVT), which can cause abdominal pain and nausea. However, patients with MVT typically have abdominal pain that is subacute (not sudden) in onset. In addition, MVT does not cause a pulsatile mass, and this patient lacks risk factors for developing MVT such as hypercoagulability and recent abdominal surgery. A dissecting AAA, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient, can cause acute mesenteric ischemia, but this results in a filling defect in the superior mesenteric artery, not the vein.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased jugular venous pressure (JVP) results from increased right ventricular end-diastolic pressure. A dissection of the proximal thoracic aorta can cause cardiac tamponade and increased JVP. This patient presents with a history concerning for aortic dissection, but his abdominal pain and pulsatile epigastric mass suggest that the dissection is localized to the abdominal aorta, not the thoracic aorta. A dissecting abdominal aortic aneurysm does not cause increased JVP.

E) CORRECT:

A decreased ankle-brachial index indicates decreased blood flow to a lower extremity when compared to an upper extremity. This finding is most commonly seen in peripheral artery disease but can also occur in patients with a large, ruptured and/or dissecting AAA. In AAA dissection, blood accumulates in the intima-media space of the dissected arterial wall, which may lead to narrowing of the aortic lumen resulting in obstructed blood flow to the lower extremities and therefore, to a decreased ankle-brachial index.
questions.hint: Acute onset abdominal pain and a pulsatile abdominal mass in a patient with multiple cardiovascular risk factors should raise concern for a dissecting abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man presents for a routine examination. He has a 45-year history of heavy smoking and poorly controlled hypertension. He complains of mild lower back aching but denies acute pain. Examination reveals a pulsatile, nontender mass in the epigastric region. He has no fever or notable abdominal tenderness.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Retroperitoneal liposarcoma presents as a slowly enlarging, non-pulsatile mass. The pulsatile nature of the mass in this patient suggests a vascular origin.

B) INCORRECT:

Epigastric hernias involve protrusion through the linea alba and do not exhibit a pulsatile rhythm. They become more prominent with increased intra-abdominal pressure, not with each heartbeat.

C) CORRECT:

Abdominal aortic aneurysm manifests with a pulsatile, nontender mass in the epigastric region that enlarges with each heartbeat. This condition is associated with risk factors such as advanced age, heavy smoking, and poorly controlled hypertension, which contribute to atherosclerotic changes and weakening of the aortic wall. The mild lower back ache may result from pressure effects on surrounding tissues. Diagnosis is confirmed with imaging, such as abdominal ultrasound, to assess the aneurysm's size and extent.

Key learning point: A pulsatile supra-umbilical mass in a patient with risk factors such as smoking and hypertension is highly suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

D) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic pseudocysts develop after acute or chronic pancreatitis, often linked to alcohol use or biliary disease. They do not exhibit a pulsatile nature.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a six-hour history of sudden-onset severe epigastric pain radiating to his back. He feels increasingly lightheaded and nauseated but denies vomiting. He has a 45-year history of smoking and hypertension controlled with medication. He denies alcohol use and has never experienced similar pain before. Physical examination reveals abdominal tenderness with guarding in the epigastric region. Serum lipase is 20 U/L (reference range: 0–160 U/L).


Heart rate
120/min


Blood pressure
86/55 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
22/min


Temperature
36.8°C


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?

choices.text: Endoscopic evaluation of the upper gastrointestinal tract
Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Sudden-onset severe epigastric pain radiating to the back in a hemodynamically unstable patient with a history of smoking and hypertension raises suspicion for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. A pulsatile mass is characteristic of this condition but may not be palpable in all patients (especially if significant guarding is present). Urgent bedside point-of-care ultrasound is a rapid, non-invasive diagnostic tool that can quickly evaluate for aortic dilation, intraperitoneal or periaortic fluid collections, and retroperitoneal hemorrhage. It is useful for diagnosis of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm in unstable patients, in whom early intervention is critical to prevent further deterioration. The initial management includes pain management and hemodynamic support with permissive hypotension; vasopressors and inotropes should be used with caution. An urgent vascular surgery and anesthesia consult should be obtained with a goal of definitive treatment (via endovascular or open surgical repair) within 90 minutes.

Key learning point: In a hemodynamically unstable patient with sudden severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, consider a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm and perform a bedside point-of-care ultrasound.

B) INCORRECT:

Endoscopy is used for gastrointestinal pathologies, such as peptic ulcers or bleeding. The patient's presentation suggests a life-threatening condition affecting a major artery. Upper GI endoscopy could delay the necessary vascular intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

In a patient with acute pancreatitis, serum lipase levels increase within 3–6 hours of disease onset, reaching a maximum after approximately 24 hours. The clinical presentation and the normal initial lipase level suggest a life-threatening condition affecting a major artery. Repeating lipase measurement would be inappropriate as the next step in evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Contrast-enhanced CT is valuable for diagnosing abdominal aortic aneurysms in stable patients, providing detailed anatomical information. However, in hemodynamically unstable patients, detailed imaging is not performed as delays can be detrimental.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man comes to the Outpatient Clinic for routine health maintenance evaluation. He has a 50-pack-year smoking history and hypertension. He reports occasional abdominal pain but otherwise feels well. Physical examination is normal (see report).
Abdominal ultrasound: Infrarenal abdominal aorta approximately 7.5 cm in diameter
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen
Repeat abdominal ultrasound in six months
MRI of the abdomen without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) provides high-resolution detail of the vascular lumen but is invasive and primarily assesses the vessel lumen without detailed information about the aortic wall or surrounding tissues. Noninvasive modalities with greater anatomical detail are preferred for initial evaluation, as DSA carries risks such as catheter-related complications.

B) CORRECT:

Dilatation of the aorta ≥ 3 cm raises is consistent with an aortic aneurysm. Contrast-enhanced CT scanning provides high-resolution images that allow for precise measurement of aneurysm size and detailed visualization of its morphology and anatomical relations, including branch vessel involvement. CT imaging also offers essential information on thrombus presence, wall integrity, and signs of impending rupture, guiding management decisions and surgical planning. Intravenous contrast enhances the differentiation between vascular structures and surrounding tissues.

Key learning point: A CT angiogram is the most appropriate diagnostic test for confirmation and presurgical evaluation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

C) INCORRECT:

If a large aneurysm (≥ 5.5 cm in men, ≥ 5.0 cm in women) is seen on ultrasound in a patient presenting with abdominal pain, immediate further evaluation and a referral for treatment are necessary. Moreover, an ultrasound may not accurately characterize aneurysm features such as extent, mural thrombus, or branch vessel involvement; this information is necessary for intervention planning.

D) INCORRECT:

An MRI without contrast cannot clearly delineate vascular structures; contrast is necessary for visualizing the lumen, mural thrombus, and aneurysm wall integrity.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman comes to your clinic for follow-up. One year ago, she was diagnosed with a 4-cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm found incidentally on abdominal ultrasound. She reports feeling well. Her medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and COPD. Her current medications are hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, glyburide, and an albuterol inhaler. She has a 45-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. Her temperature is 37°C, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. On examination, a faint abdominal bruit is heard. Abdominal ultrasonography now shows a 5.1-cm saccular dilation of the infrarenal aorta. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and follow-up CT in 6 months.
Adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and follow-up ultrasound in 12 months.
Adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and follow-up ultrasound in 6 months.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conservative management of AAA includes adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and aneurysm surveillance. This approach is indicated for an asymptomatic AAA that is not rapidly expanding and is < 5.5 cm in men or < 5 cm in women. In addition, duplex ultrasonography is the preferred imaging modality for AAA surveillance because it is as accurate as CT angiography for assessing aneurysm diameter, less expensive, and does not require administration of IV contrast or radiation exposure.

B) CORRECT:

Elective surgical repair is indicated for large asymptomatic AAAs (≥ 5.5 cm in men; ≥ 5.0 cm in women), rapidly expanding AAAs (≥ 0.5 cm/6 months), saccular aneurysms, and/or symptomatic AAAs (as these are most likely to rupture) regardless of size. This patient has a saccular AAA that has rapidly grown over the past year and therefore requires surgery. Endovascular aneurysm repair is recommended for AAA in patients with suitable anatomy because it is minimally invasive and can be performed under local anesthesia. Furthermore, this approach is preferred in individuals with high operative risk, such as this patient with multiple comorbidities.

Key learning point: Elective endovascular repair is indicated for abdominal aortic aneurysms in women ≥5.0 cm, rapidly expanding, saccular, or symptomatic aneurysms, especially in patients with high surgical risk.

C) INCORRECT:

Conservative management of AAA includes adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and aneurysm surveillance with ultrasound. This approach is indicated for an asymptomatic AAA that is not rapidly expanding and is < 5.5 cm in men or < 5 cm in women (see “Follow-up frequency for AAA surveillance” table). Elective repair rather than conservative management is indicated for a rapidly expanding AAA.

D) INCORRECT:

Although elective surgical repair is indicated for this patient's AAA, she has a high operative risk due to multiple comorbidities. Another step in management is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Conservative management of AAA includes adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and aneurysm surveillance with ultrasound. This approach is indicated for an asymptomatic AAA that is not rapidly expanding and is < 5.5 cm in men or < 5 cm in women (see “Follow-up frequency for AAA surveillance” table). Elective repair rather than conservative management is indicated for a rapidly expanding AAA.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a rapidly expanding abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).

questions.text: You are seeing a 71-year-old man with hypertension who is brought to the emergency department because of sudden onset of stabbing abdominal pain radiating to the back. He has a 20-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. His pulse is 120/min and thready, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 82/54 mm Hg. On examination, there is a periumbilical, pulsatile mass with an abdominal bruit and epigastric tenderness. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his current condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The pathophysiology of AAA is not fully understood, but numerous genetic and environmental factors, such as smoking, are believed to cause inflammation and proteolysis of connective tissue within the aortic wall. This leads to loss of structural integrity and weakening of the aorta. Other risk factors for AAA include advanced age and male sex. When high aortic wall stress is applied, as in hypertension, further weakening, widening, and rupture of the aortic wall can occur. AAAs are most commonly located below the renal arteries (infrarenal).

Key learning point: Ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm results from chronic aortic wall weakening and increased wall stress, often due to hypertension and smoking, leading to loss of structural integrity and vessel rupture.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; arterial phase; axial plane)

An infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm is measured as 8 cm in transverse diameter. Contrast extravasation (dashed outline) is seen on the left side at the site of rupture (arrowhead). A large left retroperitoneal hematoma (yellow overlay) extends inferiorly into the inguinal canal. Additional intraperitoneal fluid is seen in the pelvis and right upper quadrant (red overlay).

B) INCORRECT:

Coronary atherosclerosis resulting in narrowing of the vessel lumen is involved in the pathophysiology of angina pectoris and myocardial infarction (MI). Coronary atherosclerosis leads to narrowing of the arterial lumen, which decreases the blood flow to the myocardium. During exercise, myocardial flow is unable to meet increased myocardial demand, which causes myocardial ischemia and symptoms of angina. While smoking increases the risk for MI, this man's history of acute onset, stabbing abdominal pain with an umbilical mass and hypotension suggest a different disease process.

C) INCORRECT:

Mesenteric atherosclerosis is involved in the pathophysiology of chronic mesenteric ischemia, in which intestinal blood flow is reduced. In the postprandial period, there is a mismatch between low splanchnic blood flow and high intestinal metabolic demand, which leads to postprandial ischemia and abdominal pain within one hour of eating. Bloating, nausea, and weight loss due to food aversion are common symptoms. This patient has acute-onset, stabbing abdominal pain with an umbilical mass and hypotension, features that suggest a different, more emergent disease process.

D) INCORRECT:

Portal vein stasis predisposes patients to the formation of acute portal vein thrombosis, which manifests with right upper quadrant or generalized abdominal pain. Portal vein thrombosis often arises as a complication of cirrhosis, but this patient lacks symptoms of chronic liver disease (jaundice, pruritus, hepatosplenomegaly, telangiectasias, caput medusae, gynecomastia). Furthermore, this patient's periumbilical mass and abdominal bruit suggest a different cause for his symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Abdominal wall defects can predispose patients to hernia formation. Uncomplicated hernias are typically asymptomatic and occur when intraabdominal contents protrude through congenital defects or areas of weakness in the abdominal wall. Complicated hernias include incarcerated hernias (irreducible), strangulated hernias (disrupted blood supply), or obstructed hernias (kinked intestine), and typically manifest with acute pain at the site of the hernia and possible bowel obstruction. Although this patient has a periumbilical mass, he also has an abdominal bruit and hypotension, suggesting a different etiology for his symptoms.
questions.hint: Abdominal pain radiating to the back, a pulsatile abdominal mass, and new-onset hypotension in a man with a history of smoking and hypertension should raise concerns for a certain pathology.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. Over the past year, he has experienced difficulty initiating urination and a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. His medical history includes hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. questions.hint: This patient has a history of smoking, hypercholesterolemia, and arterial hypertension and presents with a pulsatile abdominal mass and a bruit on auscultation. These features are suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He does not have abdominal, back, or flank pain, flank ecchymoses, or signs of hemodynamic instability that would suggest rupture.
