Fragmentation of elastic tissue in the tunica media is the pathological process underlying cystic medial necrosis (CMN), which occurs in certain connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome. However, for reasons that are not completely understood, CMN typically affects the thoracic aorta rather than the abdominal aorta. A different pathological process is the most common cause of an AAA. Furthermore, this patient does not have features of Marfan syndrome (e.g., tall stature, long extremities, joint hypermobility, ectopia lentis).

C) CORRECT:

Accumulation of foam cells in the tunica intima is the pathological process underlying atheroma formation (atherosclerosis), which is the most common cause of aortic wall weakening and formation of an AAA. This patient's history of smoking, hypertension, and advanced age are all risk factors for atherosclerosis.

Key learning point: Abdominal aortic aneurysm most commonly results from atherosclerosis, characterized by accumulation of foam cells and lipid-laden plaques in the tunica intima, leading to weakening of the vessel wall.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a section of an arterial wall depicting an atheroma (H&E, highly magnified)

The inner layer of an atheroma is the single layer of endothelial cells of the tunica intima (the superior-most layer in this image).
The second layer is a fibrous cap, which is composed of lipid-laden macrophages or foam cells (the white arrowheads point to a few examples), a few smooth muscle cells, neutrophils, and lymphocytes.
The core of the atheroma (green overlay) is composed of anuclear necrotic cells and cholesterol clefts (empty unstained spaced indicated with white arrows).

A collection of foam cells and cholesterol clefts with a fibrous cap and a necrotic core are the characteristic histological features of an atheroma.

D) INCORRECT:

Formation of giant cells in the tunica media is characteristic of giant cell arteritis (GCA) and Takayasu arteritis, both of which are large vessel vasculitides and can result in an AAA. However, neither condition is the most common cause of AAA, and this patient does not report any symptoms that would otherwise suggest an increased likelihood of GCA (e.g., headache, scalp tenderness, or jaw claudication) or Takayasu arteritis (e.g., limb claudication or onset of symptoms before the age of 40 years), so a different pathological process is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Necrotizing inflammation of all the layers of the vessel wall is characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), which can cause microaneurysms in medium-sized arteries (e.g., mesenteric arteries and renal arteries), episodic abdominal pain (due to mesenteric ischemia), and hypertension (due to renal involvement). However, PAN would not cause a pulsatile periumbilical mass because it spares large arteries like the aorta. Other clinical features of vasculitis, such as fever, malaise, weight loss, and cutaneous lesions (e.g., livedo reticularis, distal ulcerations), would be expected instead.
questions.hint: The presence of chronic dull abdominal pain and a pulsatile abdominal mass suggests an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a remote history of smoking (quit 20 years ago) comes to your clinic. He feels well, lives independently, and his physical examination is normal. Which one of the following screening tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the absence of symptoms, carotid ultrasonography is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

The 2023 Osteoporosis Canada guidelines recommend routine densitometry only for men over 70, and the CTFPHC advises against routinely screening men aged 40 and older. This 68-year-old man with only smoking as a minor risk factor and no history of fragility fractures or major risk factors (e.g., chronic glucocorticoid use) does not require osteoporosis screening at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

In a patient with hypertension, urinalysis (for proteinuria) and a resting electrocardiogram (for left ventricular hypertrophy) are recommended, but an exercise electrocardiogram and an echocardiogram are not.

D) CORRECT:

The Canadian Task Force on Preventive Health Care (CTFPHC) recommends one-time screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) by ultrasonography in men 65 to 80 years of age, regardless of a history of smoking. The CTFPHC cites moderate evidence that AAA screening and subsequent surgical repair of large AAAs (≥5.5 cm in diameter) in this cohort reduces AAA-specific mortality. For men older than 80 years, the CTFPHC recommends against screening. For women of any age, the CTFPHC advises against routine AAA screening.

The 2020 Canadian Society for Vascular Surgery (CSVS) guidelines endorse a more aggressive, risk stratified approach: one time ultrasound in both men and women 65 to 80 years of age who have ever smoked or who have cardiovascular disease, screening of first degree relatives of AAA patients after age 55, and, for those with ectatic aortas (2.5 to 3 cm), repeat imaging at 10 years.

Key learning point: A one-time ultrasound of the abdominal aorta is recommended for men 65 to 80 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient with hypertension, urinalysis (for proteinuria) and a resting electrocardiogram (for left ventricular hypertrophy) are recommended, but an exercise electrocardiogram and an echocardiogram are not.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with acute abdominal pain and back discomfort. Vital signs are BP, 145/90; P, 95. He appears uncomfortable but stable. Point-of-care ultrasound shows a uniform aortic appearance without wall irregularities. The aorta measures 3.2 cm in the transverse view and 3.1 cm in the longitudinal view. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT angiography and vascular surgery consultation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The aortic measurements of 3.2 cm and 3.1 cm meet the diagnostic threshold for abdominal aortic aneurysm (≥ 3 cm). In a symptomatic patient with acute abdominal and back pain, this finding warrants CT angiography for detailed evaluation and vascular surgery consultation for management planning.

B) INCORRECT:

Observation alone is insufficient when point-of-care ultrasound shows abdominal aortic aneurysm in a symptomatic patient. The combination of symptoms and confirmed aneurysm requires immediate specialist evaluation and advanced imaging to exclude rupture or impending rupture.

C) INCORRECT:

Discharge is inappropriate because the measurements exceed 3 cm, which meets the criteria for abdominal aortic aneurysm. This condition requires further evaluation and specialist consultation regardless of current stability.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical intervention is premature without confirmatory imaging and detailed evaluation. While this patient has abdominal aortic aneurysm, he appears stable and requires CT angiography first to assess for rupture and determine the most appropriate intervention approach.

E) INCORRECT:

Repeat ultrasound delays necessary care and adds no diagnostic value when clear measurements have already been obtained. The priority is advanced imaging and specialist consultation, given the confirmed abdominal aortic aneurysm in a symptomatic patient.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man who smokes and has a history of hypertension presents with an acute onset of severe tearing back pain and syncope. He is awake but appears pale and diaphoretic. Vital signs are BP, 78/45; P, 125; oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. Physical examination shows a tender, pulsatile abdominal mass and diffuse abdominal tenderness. The patient's blood pressure drops to 65/40 during your assessment. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer normal saline boluses to achieve systolic blood pressure > 100 mm Hg
Obtain emergency CT angiography to confirm the diagnosis
Perform immediate endotracheal intubation for airway protection
Administer vasopressors to maintain adequate perfusion pressure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aggressive fluid resuscitation is contraindicated in suspected ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Target systolic blood pressure should be 70–90 mm Hg (permissive hypotension) to avoid dislodging clots that may be tamponading the rupture site. Blood products may be used for resuscitation instead of intravenous fluids.

B) INCORRECT:

CT angiography should not be performed in unstable patients as CT delays definitive operative treatment. The suspected diagnosis is made clinically in hemodynamically unstable patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Elective intubation should be avoided in suspected ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm, as intubation may precipitate cardiovascular collapse due to loss of sympathetic tone and the effects of positive pressure ventilation on venous return.

D) INCORRECT:

Vasopressors should be used with extreme caution in ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Raising blood pressure may dislodge clots that help tamponade the rupture site and worsen bleeding, although vasopressors may be necessary if the patient does not respond to cautious fluid resuscitation and blood pressure remains too low for sufficient organ perfusion.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- The clinical presentation of severe tearing back pain, pulsatile abdominal mass, and progressive hypotension in an older man who smokes and has hypertension strongly suggests ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Imaging is not required to confirm the diagnosis; the goal is immediate operative repair.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with acute-onset severe low back pain radiating to his left flank that began 2 hours ago. Vital signs are BP, 150/85; P, 105; R, 18; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F). Point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) is performed to evaluate for abdominal aortic aneurysm, but overlying bowel gas prevents complete visualization of the aorta from the celiac artery to the iliac bifurcation. The visualized portions show an aortic diameter of 2.8 cm. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: CT angiography of the abdomen and pelvis
Repeat POCUS in the left lateral decubitus position
MR angiography of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Formal ultrasound has the same bowel gas limitations as POCUS and would delay definitive diagnosis in a patient with a concerning clinical presentation.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- In patients with negative or indeterminate POCUS findings, CT angiography should be performed if the pretest probability for abdominal aortic aneurysm is high. This patient has classic risk factors (older age, smoking) and symptoms (acute severe back pain with flank radiation) that warrant advanced imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Serial POCUS examinations would not overcome the bowel gas limitations in this patient and would delay definitive evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

While lateral positioning can improve visualization if bowel gas interferes, additional POCUS attempts may not overcome the technical limitations for this patient and may delay definitive management. Additionally, POCUS cannot be used to rule out a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm as it has low sensitivity for rupture in the retroperitoneal space.

E) INCORRECT:

MR angiography has a prolonged duration, which makes it inappropriate in the emergency setting if rapid diagnosis is needed for potentially life-threatening conditions.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of smoking presents with low back pain. During bedside ultrasound evaluation, overlying bowel gas obscures portions of the abdominal aorta, but a 4.8-cm tubular structure with thick walls and strong pulsatility in the transverse plane is clearly visualized. The structure remains noncompressible with pressure. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Switch to linear transducer for better resolution
Document the finding as a normal aorta based on the area visualized
Measure the inner luminal diameter to determine if there is an  aneurysm
Position patient in left lateral decubitus and scan through the liver
Rock the transducer back and forth while applying firm pressure to displace bowel gas

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Linear transducers lack the penetration depth needed for adequate visualization of the abdominal aorta. The preferred transducers for aortic point-of-care ultrasound are curvilinear or phased array, which provide better penetration for deep abdominal structures.

B) INCORRECT:

An aortic diameter measuring 4.8 cm represents aneurysmal dilatation, not a normal aorta. Additionally, bowel gas interference should prompt troubleshooting techniques rather than abandoning the study, as successful gas displacement often allows for complete aortic evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Measuring only the inner lumen of the aorta may underestimate the size of the aorta, as an intraluminal clot may mimic the aortic wall. The correct measurement technique requires measuring from outer wall to outer wall at the greatest width of the aorta to obtain the true diameter of the aneurysm.

D) INCORRECT:

Lateral positioning with scanning through the liver is an alternative technique if initial troubleshooting fails. However, it is not the first-line approach if bowel gas obstructs the view.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- The sonographic features described (4.8 cm diameter, thick walls, strong pulsatility, noncompressible, left-sided location) are consistent with abdominal aortic aneurysm. If bowel gas obstructs the view, the first troubleshooting step is to attempt displacement by rocking the transducer back and forth while applying firm but gentle pressure over the area of interest. This technique can successfully displace bowel gas to allow for complete visualization of the aorta, from the celiac artery to the iliac bifurcation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, nausea, and three episodes of large-volume, dark tarry stools over the past 6 hours. He had open infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm repair with synthetic graft placement 15 months ago and takes aspirin for cardiovascular protection. Vital signs are BP, 88/52; P, 116; T, 37.8°C (100.0°F). Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and mild periumbilical tenderness without guarding or rebound. Hemoglobin is 8.1 g/dL (baseline 12.8 g/dL). What is the most appropriate initial management approach?

choices.text: Crystalloid resuscitation and serial hemoglobin monitoring
CT abdomen and pelvis with oral and intravenous contrast
Urgent upper endoscopy to localize bleeding source
Nasogastric tube placement and gastric lavage

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of melena, hemodynamic instability, and prior aortic graft repair raises high suspicion for aortoenteric fistula. This life-threatening complication can result from graft infection or mechanical irritation from prosthetic material and requires immediate vascular surgery consultation for urgent evaluation and management because the patient is hemodynamically unstable.

B) INCORRECT:

Although crystalloid resuscitation and hemoglobin monitoring are appropriate supportive measures, they do not address this patient's underlying surgical emergency. The clinical presentation of melena in a hemodynamically unstable patient with prior aortic graft repair requires immediate vascular surgery consultation.

C) INCORRECT:

While CT imaging may eventually be helpful for diagnosis, the priority in this unstable patient with clinical findings suggestive of aortoenteric fistula is immediate surgical consultation. Delaying surgical evaluation to obtain imaging could be life-threatening.

D) INCORRECT:

Upper endoscopy is not the appropriate initial step in this hemodynamically unstable patient with prior aortic graft repair who presents with melena. The clinical presentation raises high suspicion for aortoenteric fistula, a condition that requires immediate surgical consultation in hemodynamically unstable patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Nasogastric tube placement and gastric lavage are inappropriate for this patient because they do not address the cause of the potentially life-threatening melena.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the office because of a one-week history of constant, deep, gnawing mid-abdominal pain that radiates to the back. He has no fever, chills, or changes in bowel habits. He has a history of hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His pulse is 82/min and blood pressure is 145/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a soft and non-tender abdomen. There is a poorly defined, pulsatile periumbilical fullness on deep palpation. Distal pulses are intact and symmetric. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial imaging study to evaluate this patient's condition?

choices.text: CT angiography of the abdomen and pelvis
Magnetic resonance angiography of the abdomen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography (CTA) provides excellent anatomical detail of an AAA, including its size, extent, and relationship to branch vessels like the renal arteries. While it is the gold standard for preoperative planning, it is not the best initial test for a stable patient due to radiation exposure, use of intravenous contrast, and higher cost. Ultrasound is sufficient to make the initial diagnosis and determine size.

B) INCORRECT:

Mesenteric duplex ultrasonography is a specialized study used to evaluate blood flow in the mesenteric arteries to diagnose conditions like chronic mesenteric ischemia, which can cause abdominal pain. This patient's clinical presentation, particularly the pulsatile mass and back pain, points towards an aortic pathology, not a primary mesenteric vessel issue, making this test inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

An abdominal radiograph might incidentally show calcification outlining the wall of an aneurysm, sometimes called an 'eggshell sign.' However, it has very low sensitivity for detecting an AAA and cannot be used to reliably rule out the diagnosis or measure its size. Therefore, it is not an appropriate imaging modality for evaluating this patient's condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) can accurately visualize the aorta and its branches without using ionizing radiation. However, it is more time-consuming, less widely available, and more expensive than ultrasound or CT. MRA is typically reserved for pre-operative planning in patients with a contraindication to iodinated contrast used in CT angiography, such as severe renal insufficiency.

E) CORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasound is the preferred initial diagnostic study in patients with abdominal pain and suspected AAA. It is non-invasive, readily available, does not expose the patient to ionizing radiation, and is nearly 100% sensitive and specific for detecting an AAA. The primary goal of the initial imaging is to confirm the presence of an aneurysm and, most importantly, to measure the maximal aortic diameter, which is the key determinant for management and surveillance intervals.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation, including age, smoking history, hypertension, abdominal pain radiating to the back, and a pulsatile abdominal mass, should raise suspicion for a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is seen for a routine health examination. He is asymptomatic. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, managed with lisinopril and atorvastatin. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His blood pressure is 138/84 mm Hg, and his pulse is 76/min. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. As part of a screening protocol, an abdominal ultrasound is performed, which shows a 5.9-cm fusiform, infrarenal aortic aneurysm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to the hospital for emergency repair
Order a computed tomography angiogram of the abdomen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Emergency repair is indicated for symptomatic or ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms, which manifest with acute abdominal or back pain, hypotension, and often a pulsatile abdominal mass. This patient is asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable.

B) INCORRECT:

A computed tomography angiogram is an essential part of preoperative planning for abdominal aortic aneurysm repair, as it provides detailed anatomical information about the aorta and surrounding vessels needed to determine the surgical approach (e.g., suitability for endovascular aneurysm repair). However, this is not the most appropriate next step in management.

C) INCORRECT:

While optimal medical management, including blood pressure control, is crucial for patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm to reduce cardiovascular risk and potentially slow expansion, it is not the definitive treatment for an aneurysm of this size. This patient's blood pressure is reasonably controlled on lisinopril. Adding a beta-blocker is not the most critical next step.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is 5.9 cm. For men, elective surgical repair is indicated for asymptomatic AAAs with a diameter of 5.5 cm or greater due to the substantially increased risk of rupture. The most appropriate next step is a referral to a vascular surgeon to discuss the risks and benefits of repair and determine the best surgical approach, either open repair or endovascular aneurysm repair. While awaiting consultation, aggressive risk factor modification, including strict blood pressure control and smoking cessation, should be emphasized. The referral initiates the process for definitive, life-saving treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Serial ultrasonography is the standard of care for surveillance of smaller abdominal aortic aneurysms. An ultrasound every 6–12 months is appropriate for aneurysms between 4.0 and 5.4 cm. However, this patient's aneurysm has already surpassed the 5.5-cm threshold for elective repair, making a strategy of continued surveillance inappropriate because it would delay necessary intervention and expose the patient to an unacceptably high risk of rupture.
questions.hint: The management of an asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm is primarily determined by its diameter. The risk of rupture increases significantly once the aneurysm exceeds a specific size threshold, warranting consideration for elective repair.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic with a 3-week history of persistent, dull mid-abdominal pain that radiates to his lower back. He describes the pain as a deep, gnawing sensation. He has a history of hypertension. He smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years, but he quit 5 years ago. His blood pressure is 148/86 mm Hg, and his pulse is 78/min. Physical examination shows a prominent, non-tender pulsatile mass palpated in the periumbilical region. The remainder of his examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial imaging study to confirm the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance angiography of the abdomen
CT angiography of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasonography is the preferred initial imaging modality for diagnosing and monitoring a suspected AAA in a hemodynamically stable patient. It is non-invasive, readily available, cost-effective, and does not expose the patient to ionizing radiation or intravenous contrast. This imaging technique is highly sensitive and specific for detecting the presence of an aneurysm and accurately measuring its maximal anteroposterior aneurysm diameter, which is the primary factor guiding surveillance intervals and the need for surgical intervention. For this patient, whose symptoms and physical examination findings strongly suggest a stable, symptomatic AAA, ultrasound is the most appropriate first step to confirm the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) can accurately visualize the aorta and diagnose an aneurysm without using ionizing radiation. However, MRA is more expensive, less widely available, and more time-consuming than the preferred test, making it an unsuitable choice for the initial confirmation of a suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm in a stable patient.

C) INCORRECT:

CT angiography (CTA) provides detailed anatomical information about an aneurysm, including its relationship to the renal arteries, and is the gold standard for preoperative planning. However, it involves significant radiation exposure and the use of intravenous contrast, which carries a risk of nephropathy. For a hemodynamically stable patient, CTA is not the recommended initial diagnostic test but is reserved for surgical planning after the diagnosis is confirmed or if rupture is suspected.

D) INCORRECT:

Mesenteric duplex ultrasonography is a specialized study used to evaluate blood flow in the mesenteric arteries, typically to diagnose mesenteric ischemia. While the patient has abdominal pain, the presence of a pulsatile mass directly suggests an aortic pathology rather than a primary mesenteric vessel issue. This test is not designed to assess the size and morphology of the aorta itself.

E) INCORRECT:

An abdominal radiograph may incidentally show curvilinear calcifications in the wall of a large, chronic aneurysm, sometimes called an 'eggshell' sign. However, this finding is not always present, and the study is neither sensitive nor specific for diagnosing an AAA. It cannot provide crucial information about the aneurysm's size or extent, making it an inappropriate initial diagnostic tool.
questions.hint: This patient's risk factors (hypertension, smoking), back pain, and a pulsatile abdominal mass are highly suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).
